table.name: Summary
table.caption: M. genitalium taxonomy and cross references.

column.name: Taxonomy
column.description: Organism taxonomy: no rank, superkingdom, phylum, class, order, family, family, genus, species, strain

column.name: Transcription Units
column.description: Number of knowledge base transcription units

column.name: Genome Features
column.description: Number of knowledge base genome features

column.name: Protein Monomers
column.description: Number of knowledge base protein monomers

column.name: Protein Complexes
column.description: Number of knowledge base protein complexes

column.name: References
column.description: Number of knowledge base literature references

table.name: Simulation
table.caption: M. genitalium Whole Cell Model simulations.

table.name: State
table.caption: 16 MATLAB classes represent the instantaneous state of M. genitalium as well as the allowable state transitions. Each class is parameterized by distinct experimental data. Additionally allowable state transitions among the Chromosome state are parameteried by pseudoreactions.

column.name: ID
column.instructions: Enter unique string containing only the characters 'a-z0-9_'

column.name: Class
column.instructions: Enter the name of MATLAB state class

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Process
table.caption: The M. genitalium Whole Cell Model is hybrid computational model composed of 28 submodels of distinct cellular processes and biochemical reactions. Each submodel is implemented as a MATLAB class using different mathematical representations and is trained using different experimental data. The submodels are initialized in the order indicated here.

column.name: ID
column.instructions: Enter unique string containing only the characters 'a-z0-9_'

column.name: Initialization Order
column.description: Order in which processes are initialized at the beginning of each simulation

column.name: Evaluation Order
column.description: Order in which processes are evaluated at each time step of each simulation

column.name: Class
column.instructions: Enter the name of MATLAB process class

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Parameter
table.caption: The M. genitalium Whole Cell Model is a hybrid computational model composed of 28 submodels each represented by distinct mathematics and training using different experimental data organized as a knowledge base. The majority of the experimental data used the train the model is organized into structured tables. All experimental data which not organized into structured tables is represented as a "parameter" in the table below. This table indicates the value, dimension, and source of each parameter and the state, process, reaction, and/or molecule which the parameter describes.

column.name: Name
column.instructions: Enter a valid MATLAB variable name

column.name: Index
column.description: Index of parameter within MATLAB variable
column.instructions: Enter a valid MATLAB variable name

column.name: Experimentally Constrained
column.description: Whether or not the value of the parameter is constrained by experimental measurement

column.name: Process
column.description: Process within simulation where parameter is used

column.name: State
column.description: State within simulation where parameter is used

column.name: Reactions
column.description: Reaction(s) within simulation where parameter is used

column.name: Molecules
column.description: Molecule(s) within simulation where parameter is used

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Compartment
table.caption: The M. genitalium Whole Cell Model is implemented as a compartment model. Each compartment is assumed to be well-stirred on model's time-scale of 1 s.

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Pathway
table.caption: The M. genitalium metabolic network is organized into 66 pathways. The model contains no explicit mathematical representation of a metabolic pathway. Pathways provide form a conceptual organizational scheme for the M. genitalium netabolic network.

column.name: Reactions
column.description: List of reactions that participate in each pathway

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Stimulus
table.caption: The M. genitalium Whole Cell Model represents 10 external stimuli including temperature, several types of radiation, and 3 conceptual stress conditions. Each external stimulus has a specific effect in the model. Temperature modulates the activity of the transcriptional regulator HrcA and thereby modulates RNA expression. Radiation induces various types of DNA damage. Gluconate, iron, and thiol stress module the activity of various enzymes and transcriptional regulators.

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Stimulus Value
table.caption: The M. genitalium Whole Cell Model represents 10 external stimuli including temperature, several types of radiation, and 3 conceptual stress conditions. Each stimulus can be set to a distinct value at each time step. This table indicates the values of the stimuli at each time step of the Whole Cell Model simulations.

column.name: Compartment
column.description: Compartment in which stimulus is applied

column.name: Final Time (s)
column.instructions: Enter a number or leave blank to indicate that stimulus is never removed. Set equal to initial time to indicate a transient stimulus or initial condition

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Metabolite
table.caption: The M. genitalium Whole Cell Model represents 722 small molecules. This table describes the physical properties of each metabolite -- empirical formula, SMILES, charge, hydrophobicity, molecular weight, volume, pKa's, pI, logP, logD, and maximal uptake and efflux rates. The molecular weight, volume, pKa's, pI, logP, and logD of each metabolite were calculated using ChemAxon Marvin. The table also lists a two-level classification over metabolites, notes cross references for each metabolite into external databases, and indicates the reactions in which each metabolite participates.

column.name: Empirical Formula
column.instructions: Enter a valid empirical formula, eg. C6H12O6

column.name: SMILES
column.description: Line notation for describing molecular structures, see http://www.daylight.com/dayhtml/doc/theory/theory.smiles.html

column.name: Exchange Lower Bound (mmol/gDCW/h)
column.description: FBA exchange reaction rate lower bound (mmol/gDCW/h)

column.name: Exchange Upper Bound (mmol/gDCW/h)
column.description: FBA exchange reaction rate upper bound (mmol/gDCW/h)

column.name: Reactions
column.description: List of reactions in which chemical participates as reactant and/product

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Media
table.caption: M. genitalium Whole Cell Model media composition. The media composition is based on the experimentally characterized composition of the SP4 media on which M. genitalium is cultured, with additional essential molecules added to support in-silico cellular growth. Non-gaseos molecules are added to the extracellular environment at the beginning of the simulation and either drain or accumulate over the length of the simulation. Gaseos molecules are continuously perfused into the extracellular environment and are maintained at a constant concentration throughout the simulation.

column.name: Compartment
column.description: Compartment where metabolite concentration is fixed

column.name: Initial Time (s)
column.description: Time (s) when metabolite perturbation is applied

column.name: Final Time (s)
column.description: Time (s) when metabolite perturbation is removed
column.instructions: Enter a number or leave blank to indicate that perturbation is never removed. Set equal to initial time to indicate a transient perturbation or initial condition

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Biomass
table.caption: The small molecule composition of the dry mass of M. genitalium was compiled from several experimental studies. See knowledge base reconstruction for more information.

column.name: Compartment
column.description: Compartment of metabolite in flux balance analysis metabolic objective

column.name: Composition (molecules / cell)
column.description: Coefficient of metabolite in flux balance analysis metabolic objective (molecules / cell)

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Gene
table.caption: M. genitalium contains 525 gemes. This table lists the genomic coordinate of each gene -- start coordinate, length, direction; the type of each gene amd codon and amino acid for tRNA genes; the experimentally characterized essentiality of each gene; the observed expression of each gene under physiologic, cold and heat shock condition; and the observed half-life of each RNA transcript. The table also lists several calculated properties of each gene -- the sequence and G/C content of gene, the molecular weight and pI of each transcript, and the refined RNA transcript half life, decay rate, synthesis rate, and RNA polymerase binding probability accounting for operon structure. Additionally the table lists the homologs of each gene in several related organisms, cross references for each gene in external databases, the transcription unit into which each gene is organized, and the reactions in which each gene product participates.

column.name: E. coli
column.description: homologous E. coli gene locus tag (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene)

column.name: Amino Acid
column.description: Amino acid transferred to each tRNA

column.name: Coordinate
column.description: Genomic start coordinate of each gene

column.name: G/C Content
column.description: Percent G/C content of each gene

column.name: Molecular Weight
column.description: Calculated molecular weight of each nascent RNA species

column.name: Essential
column.description: Experimentally observed esssentiality of each gene

column.name: Expression
column.description: Relative expression of each gene at 37C

column.name: Expression Cold Shock
column.description: Relative expression of each gene at 32C

column.name: Expression Heat Shock
column.description: Relative expression of each gene at 43C

column.name: Half Life (min, Experimental)
column.description: Experimentally observed half life of each RNA species (min)

column.name: Half Life (min, Calculated)
column.description: Calculated half life of each RNA species (min)

column.name: Decay Constant
column.description: Decay constant of each RNA species (1/min)

column.name: Synthesis Rate
column.description: Relative synthesis rate of each RNA species

column.name: RNA Polymerase Binding Probability
column.description: Relative RNA polymerase binding probability of each gene

column.name: Transcription Unit
column.description: Unit in which gene is transcribed

column.name: Reactions
column.description: Reactions in which gene product participates as enzyme

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Transcription Unit
table.caption: The M. genitalium genomic model is organized into 335 transcription units. The transcription unit structure reconstruction was based primarily on the transcription unit structure of M. pneumoniae experimentally defined by Gell and colleagues [PUB_0418] and the promoter sites predicted by Weiner and colleagues [PUB_0411]. See knowledge base reconstruction for more details. The genomic locations of each transcription unit were calculated that from of its constituent genes.

column.name: Coordinate
column.description: Genomic start coordinate of transcription unit

column.name: -35 Promoter Box Coordinate
column.description: Genomic coordinate of -35 promoter box, relative to transcription unit coordinate

column.name: -10 Promoter Box Coordinate
column.description: Genomic coordinate of -10 promoter box, relative to transcription unit coordinate

column.name: TSS Coordinate
column.description: Genomic coordinate of transcription start site (TSS), relative to transcription unit coordinate

column.name: Synthesis Rate
column.description: Relative synthesis rate of each RNA species

column.name: Compartment
column.description: Compartment in which each transcription unit is transcribed

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Genome Feature
table.caption: In addition to genes, transcription units, and promoters, the M. gentialium genomic model contains 3 types of genomic features -- DnaA boxes, restriction/modification (R/M) sites, and short tandem repeats. The locations of DnaA boxes and R/M sites were predicted based on consensus sequences. Short tandem repeats were reconstructed from predictions by Ma et al [PUB_0183] and Washio et al [PUB_0184]; see knowledge base construction for more information. This table also encodes genomic location of the proteolysis tag of the tmRNA gene. Additionally this tables indicates the genes and transcription units which overlap each genomic feature.

column.name: Genes
column.description: Gene(s) which overlap with each feature

column.name: TranscriptionUnits
column.description: Transcription units which overlap with each feature

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Protein Monomer
table.caption: M. genitalium protein monomer physical properties -- localization, signal sequence, N-terminal methionine cleavage, prothesthic groups, chaperone requirements, topology, reaction catalysis, and DNA footprint, were reconstructed from a variety of sources (see knowledge base reconstruction for more information). The sequence, molecular formula, weight, pI, instability, stability, aliphatic index, GRAVY, extinction coefficient, and absorption were calculated for each protein monomer from the DNA sequence of the corresponding gene.

column.name: Gene
column.description: Genes which code for each protein

column.name: Empirical Formula
column.instructions: Enter a valid empirical formula, eg. C6H12O6

column.name: Half Life
column.description: Calculated half life (min) using N-end rule, see http://ca.expasy.org/tools/protparam-doc.html

column.name: GRAVY
column.description: Calculated Grand Average of Hydropathy (GRAVY), see http://ca.expasy.org/tools/protparam-doc.html

column.name: Complex
column.description: Protein complexes in which protein monomer participates

column.name: DNA Footprint (nt)
column.description: Number of bases of DNA protein occupies when bound to DNA

column.name: Compartment
column.description: Compartment in which mature protein monomer localizes

column.name: Signal Sequence Type
column.description: Type of each protein monomer signal sequence

column.name: Signal Sequence Location
column.description: Amino acid coordinate of signal sequence start

column.name: Prosthetic Groups
column.description: Small molecules required for proper protein structure and function

column.name: Chaperones
column.description: Chaperones required to fold each protein

column.name: Reactions
column.description: Reactions in which each complex participats as enzyme

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Complex
table.caption: M. genitalium macromolecular complex physical properties -- subunit and small molecule composition, localization, prosthetic groups, disulfide bonds, chaperone requirements, DNA footprint, and reaction catalysis, were reconstructed from a variety of sources (see knowledge base reconstruction for more information). The molecular weight of each complex was calculated based on its subunit composition.

column.name: Biosynthesis
column.description: RNA and protein subunits of each macromolecular complex

column.name: Half Life
column.description: Calculated half life (min) using N-end rule

column.name: Reactions
column.description: Reactions in which each complex participats as enzyme

column.name: DNA Footprint (nt)
column.description: Number of bases of DNA protein occupies when bound to DNA

column.name: Compartment
column.description: Compartment in which each mature complex localizes

column.name: Prosthetic Groups
column.description: Small molecules required for proper structure and function

column.name: Chaperones
column.description: Chaperones required to fold each complex

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Reaction
table.caption: M. genitalium chemical reaction physical properties -- small molecule stoichiometry, thermodynamics, kinetics, cofactors, and enzyme catalysis, were reconstructed from a variety of sources (see knowledge base reconstruction for more information).

column.name: Process
column.description: Process in which reaction is participates

column.name: State
column.description: State in which reaction is participates

column.name: Enzyme
column.description: RNA or protein which catalyzes each reaction

column.name: Enzyme Compartment
column.description: Compartment of enzyme which catalyzes each reaction

column.name: Pathways
column.description: Pathways in which each reaction participates

column.name: Spontaneous
column.description: True/false whether reaction is spontaneous, or must be catalyzed

column.name: ΔG
column.instructions: Average of experimentally observed and calculated Delta G

column.name: Coenzymes
column.description: Small molecules required for enzymatic catalysis

column.name: Bound Units
column.description: Units of upper and lower bounds

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Transcriptional Regulation
table.caption: The M. genitalium transcriptional regulatory network contains 5 transcriptional regulators and regulates 27 transcription units composed of 54 genes. This table lists the physical properties of each transcriptional regulatory interaction -- transcription factor binding site, affinity, and expression fold change effect. The transcriptional regulatory network was reconstructed from several sources.

column.name: Genes
column.description: Genes that compose each transcription unit

column.name: Transcription Factor
column.description: Protein which regulates each transcription unit

column.name: Transcription Factor Compartment
column.description: Compartment where transcription factor regulates transcription unit

column.name: Consensus Binding Sequence
column.description: Promoter element of transcription unit recognized by transcription factor

column.name: Binding Site Sequence
column.description: Genomic sequence of each transcription factor binding site

column.name: Binding Site Coordinate
column.description: Genomic start coordinate of each transcription factor binding site

column.name: Binding Site Direction
column.description: Genomic direction of each transcription factor binding site (forward/backward)

column.name: Affinity (arb)
column.description: Affinity of transcription factor for transcription unit promoter (nM)

column.name: Activity (Expression Fold Change)
column.description: Fold change effect of active transcription factor on transcripton unit expression

column.name: Condition
column.description: Conditions in which fold change effect was quantitated

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Protein Activation
table.caption: The M. genitalium Whole Cell Model includes post-translational Boolean regulatory rules governing the activity of 10 proteins. These regulatory rules are functions of external stimuli and the concentrations (mM) of antibiotics and other intracellular metabolites. The rules were reconstructed from several sources including DrugBank [PUB_0847].

column.name: Regulatory Rule
column.description: Algebraic rule describing condition in which each protein is active
column.instructions: Enter a algebraic rule, eg "!(Stimulus_1 | Stimulus_2) & Metabolite_1 > 5. Numbers (that is concentrations) should be given in units of mM."

column.name: Regulators
column.description: Regulators which effect the state of each protein

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Metabolic Map Metabolite
table.caption: M. genitalium metabolic map metabolite coordinates.

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Metabolic Map Reaction
table.caption: M. genitalium metabolic map reaction paths and label coordinates.

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]

table.name: Note
table.caption: Collection of notes describing the M. genitalium reconstruction and model design.

table.name: Reference
table.caption: The M. genitalium Whole Cell Model was trained using data curated from over 800 primary sources, databases, reviews, and books.

column.name: Citations
column.description: Knowledge base objects supported by each reference

column.name: Comments
column.instructions: Enter text, eg. Gene X causes phenotype Y [PUB_xxxa, PUB_xxxb]
